H0.text: Streak is a more reliable trait or measure to identify minerals.

H1.text: Color is a more reliable trait or measure to identify minerals.

H2.text: Shape is a more reliable trait or measure to identify minerals.

H3.text: Weight is a more reliable trait or measure to identify minerals.

A4.text: Color is the most obvious property of a mineral, but it is often non-diagnostic.

A5.text: Recognizing the habit can aid in mineral identification and description, as the crystal habit is an external representation of the internal ordered atomic arrangement.

A6.text: Most natural crystals, however, do not display ideal habits and are commonly malformed.

A7.text: An object on the Moon would weigh less than it does on Earth because of the lower gravity, but it would still have the same mass.

A8.text: If an object's weight was equivalent to 1728 carob seeds, then the object was said to weigh one Roman pound.

A9.text: Physical properties applied for classification include crystal structure and habit, hardness, lustre, diaphaneity, colour, streak, cleavage and fracture, and specific gravity.

A10.text: These can be classified into density (often given as specific gravity); measures of mechanical cohesion (hardness, tenacity, cleavage, fracture, parting); macroscopic visual properties (luster, color, streak, luminescence, diaphaneity); magnetic and electric properties; radioactivity and solubility in hydrogen chloride (HCl).
